Appendix C: Room Data Sheets and Generic Plans

text.b: A P P E N D I X A - M E E T I N G M I N U T E S

page.text: Project: Medfield Police/Fire Study and Dale St. Masterplan
Attending: Tom Erb (TE), Chair Medfield PBCC
1.01 Bill Hammer passed out the latest project schedule to review with the committee. It
was explained that the schedule reflected two public meetings and there was a
discussion during our teleconference on January 9
to have a third during the week
. We realized, however that the week of the 22
week. It was agreed that we will determine the best time for the third meeting as the
project progresses. HKT will update the schedule.
1.02 The schedule had listed a meeting with the PBCC on February 20
conceptual design alternatives and determine the preferred scheme. It was pointed
out that that week is the February school vacation week. Accordingly, we agreed to
at 7:30 AM. HKT will still have time to make any
adjustments as the preferred scheme is further developed.
1.03 The second public presentation is scheduled for March 14
that we will not have a firm budget number until March 23
and it was felt that the
committee should have a number to present to the public along with the preferred
design. The Warrant article must be submitted by early to mid-March, but a budget
number is not necessary at that point. The timing of the second public presentation
1.04 The first public informational meeting is scheduled for February 4
thought that the visioning session could be tweaked to present to the public. After
the visioning session (which occurred after this meeting) it was decided to have a
teleconference to review the details of exactly what would be presented to the
1.05 There was a general discussion regarding the existing buildings. HKT had done
another walk-through with the mechanical consultant on January 16
consultant was unable to get to the site due to the weather. He is scheduled to visit
. It was agreed that repurposing the Dale Street School
would have its challenges, but all agreed that it must be reviewed as part of the
Project: Medfield Police/Fire Study and Dale St. Masterplan
Attending: Tom Erb (TE), Chair Medfield PBCC
was reviewed. It was generally felt by all that it
was well received and that the PBCC’s goal of informing the public and maintaining
transparency was achieved. Informal feedback from those who attended seemed to
confirm the same result. The turnout was over 35 people and about 6 to 8 people
toured the fire and police facility after the formal meeting. It was agreed that the next
meeting should be held in a larger venue and perhaps it should start at 7:00 PM
Chief Meaney explained to the Committee that he had asked HKT to consider
adding a town record storage room with proper temperature and humidity controls
to the Public Services Facility program. This would replace the space that the Town
currently leases at the Hometown Weekly Building off of Jane Street. The current
space is about 500 SF and it would be inspected after the meeting. (Note: the
storeroom was observed after the meeting and it was agreed that providing a
similar space would serve the Town’s needs at this time.)
Bill Hammer updated HKT’s progress on documenting the existing buildings and
A. Base plans for the fire and police stations are completed.
B. Base plans for the Dale Street School is completed.
C. The MEP reports on the fire and police stations have been submitted to HKT.
They need to be reviewed before they are passed on to the Committee. This
will occur before the next meeting.
D. The traffic study has been on-going and Pare is waiting for the traffic counts
from the Police Department in order to complete their recommendations. Chief
Meaney will have these records gathered shortly. Chief Kingsbury would prefer
to access North Street with the new facility and that generated a discussion of
how to mitigate traffic and where to locate traffic signals. This will be addressed
by Pare as the various options are developed along with consideration of
E. The structural report for the Dale Street School is integrated into the HKT
memo that addresses the repurposing of the 1941 original building. Pare has
reviewed the structure of the present fire and police stations and they have
found no structural issues. They will evaluate the design option(s) that requires
modifications to the current building in order to identify any structural issues.
Programming: The preliminary program for the fire and police stations is completed
as a first draft and is the result of meetings with both chiefs and Alan Gould and
Don Bliss of Municipal Resources. Copies have been given to both Chief Meaney
and Chief Kingsbury. HKT will meet with both chiefs after this meeting to
incorporate their comments. The current draft anticipates a building of
Review of the Dale Street School: HKT presented a memo addressing the issues
regarding the repurposing of the Dale Street School. The body of the memo is
attached at the conclusion of these minutes. The main discussion centered on the
extent of structural retrofitting that would be caused by altering the structure and
complying with the seismic code requirements. Some of the issues that were
A. Could the Dale Street School be repurposed without tripping the 30%
threshold that would trigger many very costly code requirements? At this point,
the design team feels that it is not possible inasmuch as any repurpose would
require new MEP systems, a new fire protection system, AAB compliance and
so forth. The Assessor was asked what the assessed value of the 1941 building
would be. His records show a value of $5,586,300 for the full Dale Street
School. If the 1962 addition and the 1996 modular classrooms are removed, it
B. Why do we have to retrofit the structure for seismic events since there hasn’t
been an earthquake of any sizable measure in Massachusetts since the 17
century? Geologists predict a major earthquake anytime in the zone where
Medfield is located. Because the upgrades are demanded by the code there is
HKT asked if the Hazmat inspection of the existing fire and police buildings that was
made part of the RFP would be necessary inasmuch as a study was done by our
consultant in 2002. It was agreed that the hazardous materials in the buildings
would not have changed since 2002, but we would upgrade the cost estimates.
Next Steps: HKT will have a number of options to present at the next meeting on
. Tim Bonfatti asked if we could summarize the options with the matrix
that was presented previously with notations as to pros and cons. Eventually costs
can be added so that each option can be evaluated in terms of the cost and
Part of the mandate for the Dale Street Planning Study is to investigate the potential of repurposing the Dale Street
School. The original school was built as a high school in 1941. It consisted of a two story classroom wing and an
auditorium/gymnasium that was connected by a one story classroom wing. The building has been converted into a
fourth and fifth grade elementary school and a cafeteria/classroom was added on the north side of the original two
story classroom wing in 1962. In 1996, a small modular classroom addition was attached to the north side of the
The original 1941 school is an historic structure that the community would prefer to continue as a school or other
compatible function that would preserve the building. The original design anticipated an addition to the east side of
the auditorium/gymnasium that would be the mirror image of the present classroom and connector. The addition on
the north side of the two story classroom wing was built instead.
The Medfield School Department has submitted a Letter of Interest to the Massachusetts School Building Authority
for a major upgrade to the Dale Street School. The MSBA often discourages renovating older buildings in favor of
building newer and more efficient school buildings. This would mean that the Town of Medfield could lose a subsidy
of approximately 50% from the state if they chose to renovate the Dale Street School. A study of the Dale Street
School in 2008 by Construction Technologies Management outlined the deficiencies in the current structure. They
suggested a budget of almost $23 million to bring the building up to code and correct other problems, including
Given the historic value of the Dale Street School and the possibility that the MSBA will not support the cost of
upgrading the building, the notion of saving the original building could be accomplished by repurposing.
Our design team did a walk-through of the building with Alan Peterson who is the Facilities Director for the Medfield
Public Schools. Following the walk-through, we received electronic copies of the original working drawings for the
original school and the subsequent additions. Based on our inspection and review of the drawings and the CTM
report, we have made the following observations:
1. The original building is constructed with concrete waffle slab floors supported by interior and exterior bearing
walls. The roof structure consists of steel trusses supported by exterior bearing walls. Within the two story
classroom wing, the roof trusses are also supported by interior columns. The interior columns are supported by
the first story’s bearing walls. Making changes to the first floor would involve extensive structural modifications if
the bearing wall system was to be modified.
2. The exterior bearing walls and first story interior bearing walls consist of unreinforced masonry. Repurposing of
the building would trigger the seismic strengthening provisions of Section 101.10 of the Massachusetts Building
edition) if the work exceeds fifty percent (50%) of the aggregate area of the building. The work area is
defined by the International Existing Building Code as “…that portion or portions of a building consisting of all
3. The main floor of the original building is approximately five to six feet above grade and consequently
inaccessible. Furthermore, the new addition is more than three feet lower than the first floor of the original
classroom wing. Currently, there is an inclined chair lift to make the accessible connection between the two
buildings. Making the current building fully accessible would require at least one elevator and possibly a chairlift
in the auditorium/gymnasium wing to access the stage area. There is an existing chairlift that connects the upper
seating to the gym floor below.
4. The entire mechanical, electrical and plumbing systems need to be replaced. An addressable fire alarm and fire
suppression system will need to be added. We were told that the water service is not potable because the
5. The building might need to be properly insulated to meet the current energy code, but if not required by code, it
would be imprudent to install a high efficiency system without adding insulation.
If the Dale Street School is to be repurposed, it is felt that the 1962 addition and the 1996 modular classrooms
should be removed. We have looked at the following repurposing possibilities with the assumption that only the
Fire and Police Stations: A new public safety building would require a new apparatus bay for the fire equipment
inasmuch as the existing building could not accommodate this function. The best location for the new apparatus bay
would be on the east side of the auditorium/gymnasium wing so that the fire vehicles could access North Street or
Dale Street. Accessing on Adams Street is not a viable option due to the narrow street width and increased response
time for vehicles to access North Street which is the major north/south road in Medfield. The auditorium/gymnasium
would be renovated as part of the fire station and the link would serve as shared facilities (i.e. entry, conference
room, meeting room, etc.) for both fire and police. This would require that the Recreation Center be relocated in order
to access North Street. It might be able to remain for the time being if the fire vehicles exit on Dale Street.
We did look at modifying the auditorium/gym into an apparatus bay. To maximize the area at the gym floor level, it
would require removal of the sloping stairs and seating, which is a major structural undertaking inasmuch as this
portion is supported by piers below. If the sloped area was removed, the actual area for the apparatus would result in
three bays with fire trucks in tandem with smaller vehicles. This situation is worse than the current apparatus bay
which has access on both sides. The modification of the auditorium/gym would require removing the fire truck to
The police could be located in the Dale Street School but the level changes and footprint of the building could be
problematic with regard to a functional layout without compromises. A major problem is how to transport prisoners
from the police vehicle into the booking area. In the current police station, officers are required to transport prisoners
up a flight of exterior steps. This can be dangerous in inclement weather and it offers the prisoner an opportunity to
create an unsafe situation for themselves and the arresting officer. A rather expensive solution would be needed to
mitigate this same potential problem at the Dale Street School due to the fact that the surrounding grades are
between five and six feet below the first floor. Furthermore, the program for the police station (approximately 10,000
SF) would be substantially less than the space available in the original two story classroom wing (15,300 SF). Finally,
the redesign of the first floor to fit the programmatic requirements would require the very expensive structural
Fire, Police and Recreation Center: If we added the recreation center to the repurposing of the Dale Street School,
we would make use of the land currently occupied by the 1962 addition and the modular classrooms. The fire station
addition would have to be located on the east side of the school as described above and a new recreation center
would be built on the site of the 1962 addition. The recreation center would take some of the excess space on the
second floor of the classroom wing and complete their program with a new structure where the 1962 addition was
Recreation Center and Town Offices: This option responds to the fact that the Town of Medfield is short on office
space at the Town House on Main Street. This repurposing approach puts the new public safety complex back on
the other side of Dale Street and opens up the current recreation center site for parking.
This option has several advantages: 1) the recreation center could take over the auditorium/gym and make the space
into a community theater; 2) the connecting link and the first floor of the classroom wing could be used with minimum
changes in the space layout and 3) the second floor of the classroom wing would be utilized for town office space.
Since this is the only portion of the original building that has interior columns rather than bearing walls, the layout
could be reconfigured without extensive structural modifications. However, the seismic strengthening requirements
for unreinforced masonry walls will apply if the work area exceeds fifty percent (50%) of the aggregate area of the
The building would still need all new MEP and fire protection systems and the accessibility requirements would still
apply. Nevertheless, this would be the most economical re-use and the historic elements of the Dale Street School
Project: Medfield Police/Fire Study and Dale St. Masterplan
Attending: Tom Erb (TE), Chair Medfield PBCC
Programming: Amy Dunlap distributed copies of the final program to both chiefs
and one copy for the PBCC. HKT will put a final copy into the dropbox. The initial
program of approximately 34,000 square feet has grown to 38,277 square feet. The
additional square footage was mainly due to the increasing size of fire department
storage, police locker rooms, fitness room and police file storage, fire department
dorm rooms and incorporating the antique apparatus if the existing wood frame
garage is eliminated from the final scheme.
Revised Matrix: HKT presented the revised matrix that resulted in five options that
were presented. Each option was presented and analyzed with a preliminary
summary of pros and cons. When the cost estimating is done for the preferred
option, we will add a cost comparison analysis with the intention of balancing costs
and benefits. The preliminary matrix with pros and cons are added to the end of
these minutes. It was explained that these are concept plans and that it will not be
architecture until the preferred scheme is selected.
Mike Quinlan asked why HKT had not considered an option to split fire and police
into two separate buildings. Chief Meaney responded that there were too many
advantages of being linked in terms of operations and shared spaces. Currently,
there is approximately 6,300 square feet that is shared by both departments that
would have to be duplicated if separate facilities were provided. While everyone
agreed with Chief Meaney, it was agreed that HKT would provide a summary of
pro’s and con’s for separate buildings inasmuch as the question will more than
likely be asked in public forums. Chief Meaney promised to forward a more detailed
set of reasons for keeping the facilities combined.
Some of the comments that resulted are as follows:
1. Tim Bonfatti asked if HKT could add square foot break-downs for each option.
2. It was suggested that another one or two drive through bays for the fire station
could be achieved on options A1, B1 and D2 by moving the living quarters to
the north side of the apparatus bay and slipping the bays to the south end of
3. The traffic study is not complete and the stacking lanes and parking are very
There was a lot of discussion regarding the Dale Street School. HKT felt that
repurposing the school for fire and police would be very expensive and would result
in too many compromises inasmuch as the school configuration is so incompatible
with the needs of an updated and code compliant public safety building.
Nevertheless, there was some sentiment towards Scheme B2 which would re-
purpose the Dale Street School into a police and fire facility. It was pointed out,
however that any repurposing of the Dale Street School would be contingent on
relocating the current school. This could delay the new fire and police facility of five
years or more and a greater cost when inflation is added.
Mike Quinlan asked that HKT step back to the masterplan criteria and look at 1)
how the Dale Street area would connect to the Town Center and 2) the land-use on
both sides of Dale Street. For example, Mike could envision a new public safety
complex on the north side of Dale Street and the south side of Dale Street devoted
to recreation, including a new recreation center.
There was discussion about holding off the request for design funds until a special
Town Meeting in the fall once the study is completed.
In general, it was the consensus that Option A1 was the preferred option and that
HKT should continue to develop it further. In general, A1 could be located on the
north side of Dale Street as well depending on what masterplan options are
selected as best for the Town of Medfield. However, it was asked that HKT look into
another option of demolishing the Dale Street School and providing a new
Police/Fire Recreation Center facility on the north side of Dale Street.
1. Develop Option A1 into schematic plans
2. Create another option that removes the Dale Street School and locates a new
fire/police/recreation center on the north side of Dale Street.
3. Develop pro’s and con’s for separate fire and police stations
, 7:30 AM (Note this meeting is in lieu of the 2/26 meeting)
FIRE/POLICE STATION STUDY + DALE STREET MASTERPLAN
The following is a listing of Pros and Cons for the five conceptual schemes on the above Matrix. The conceptual schemes
Schemes A1 and C1 assumes that The Dale Street School will stand alone.
Scheme B1 assumes that the Dale Street School will remain or be repurposed for another use that is unrelated to this
Scheme B2 frees the site for another use that has not been addressed by this study.
Options A1, B1, C1 and D2 will require temporary facilities during reconstruction.
The 1962 wind and the 1996 modular classrooms at the Dale Street School will be removed for any repurposing.

Project: Medfield Police/Fire Study and Dale St. Masterplan
Attending: Tom Erb (TE), Chair Medfield PBCC
Amy Dunlap presented HKT’s analysis of the existing land use
and street conditions along the North St connection between the downtown and
Dale St. Three master planning options were shown related to the phase I and II
development of building option A1 and building option A3. Proposed improvements
included brick sidewalks, antique street lighting to replicate existing fixtures
downtown, street trees and opportunities for developing public landscaped focal
points. It was noted by the committee that several options had been explored by
other committees in Town. Tom Erb will reach out to the Downtown Study
Committee to see what planning has been done to date in the downtown area. Mike
Sullivan raised some concerns over brick sidewalks and suggested looking at brick
strips that were successfully installed along Pond St. Chief Kingsbury suggested
looking at stamped concrete crosswalks in lieu of brick crosswalks. John Nunnari
suggested the island between east and west lanes on Dale St might be looked at
The committee agreed to include the work done by HKT in the study document and
asked HKT to develop some rough numbers (linear feet of sidewalks, quantity of
light fixtures, quantity of trees, etc.) that might be used by the committee in
Rationale for Combined Police/Fire Station: HKT presented a memo outlining the
benefits in building a combined police/fire station as opposed to separate facilities.
Benefits included reduction in construction costs from sharing various building
systems and program spaces as well as numerous operational benefits outlined by
Revised Matrix and Conceptual Options: A revised matrix was presented by HKT
including a new option being explored: A3 – New Fire/Police on the North Side of
Dale Street. Amy Dunlap then presented conceptual site and building plans for
Option A1 which was divided into Phase I with the Dale St School and Pfaff Center
remaining and Phase II with the Pfaff Center demolished and the Dale St School
repurposed for a Recreation Center and Town offices.
There was a lot of discussion regarding parking quantities and location and what is
the ideal siting of the facility on the existing site. Mike Sullivan raised concerns
about parking including use of the public safety lot by the school. Tim Bonfatti
asked HKT to investigate guidelines on quantity of required school parking spaces.
Mike Quinlan raised concerns about phasing that would be required and the
impacts on construction duration and cost. Tim Bonfatti emphasized that these are
conceptual designs and there would be more time for investigation once a site is
selected. There was some discussion about the size of the facility. Tim Bonfatti
asked HKT to look at similar communities and develop some comparisons. Some
committee members were still interested in exploring a new facility on the Dale St
School site. As time was running out and HKT had not presented the A3 scheme
yet, it was agreed to continue the discussion at the next meeting.
There was a discussion about moving forward and obtaining design funds to
continue. The committee will seek $500K for design funds at the April Town
Meeting. An override vote will not be required. The current plan is to proceed with
as much design as possible and to go to Town Meeting in April 2014 for
construction funds and the remaining design fees. Tim Bonfatti asked HKT to
prepare an informal proposal of what design work could be done for $500K.
1. Develop rough numbers/quantities for the master plan improvements
3. Compare the square footage proposed with what has been done in similar
4. Develop an informal proposal for available design fees.
Project: Medfield Police/Fire Study and Dale St. Masterplan
Attending: Tom Erb (TE), Chair Medfield PBCC
This meeting was to continue the agenda from the previous meeting on March 13
Amy Dunlap presented the A3 scheme that would require demolishing the Dale
Street School and replacing it with a new fire and police station that would echo the
aesthetic of the Dale Street School. John Nunnari responded that he was not in
favor of the A3 scheme. In his opinion, the best solution was the A1 scheme that
kept the new facility on south side of Dale Street in its current location. There was a
discussion on the phasing of the project and what would be required to keep both
fire and police in operation during construction. In general, all agreed that it was
doable and the details would emerge when the detailed design gets underway.
The committee voted unanimously to pursue the A1 concept.
There was discussion about the size of the building. The current facility is less than
8,000 square feet and the preferred A1 scheme is 38,000 square feet. It was
explained that we were mandated to look at the town’s needs over the next twenty
years and to plan for growth. This was done with the help of Municipal Resources.
The principal factors that will contribute to proposed size of the program is:
1. Volunteer fire fighters are being replaced by professional fire fighters and
the need for proper dormitory space.
2. The current facility has no room for additional administrative space needed
3. The town will grow by virtue of meeting the state requirement of 10%
affordable housing and the development of the state hospital site.
4. A great deal of equipment and storage is accommodated by the wood
garage that were built by volunteers and the container.
Bill Hammer promised that HKT would prepare a memo listing the growth factors
and send it to both chiefs for their comments.
Tim Bonfatti asked if HKT could develop a graphic to show the comparison
between the proposed space program and other similar facilities, particularly
Holden. Bill Hammer has contacted MRI to see if they had any comparisons and he
is waiting for a response. (NB: Bill has since heard back and they do not have that
information.) HKT will work on a graphic and send it around for comments prior to
A question regarding standards was raised as a result of the required 60 square
foot/fireman requirement in the dormitory. The fire station standards are published
by NFPA and those for the police station are published by CALEA (Commission for
It was decided to have the public presentation on April 11
to follow up and prepare for the Town Meeting. We
will review the presentation for the public presentation at our next meeting on April
Project: Medfield Police/Fire Study and Dale St. Masterplan
Attending: Tom Erb (TE), Chair Medfield PBCC
The plans for the preferred scheme (A1) were presented along with four (4) studies
of possible elevations on North and Dale Streets. HKT emphasized that the plans
are a good reflection of what is needed to get a preliminary cost estimate although
we all agree that this is not a final design. The preferred scheme will need more
detailed discussion with both chiefs and the elevations will need even more study.
There was a brief discussion about phasing the project. The current scheme could
be phased so that the fire department would move to the DPW garage allowing the
existing fire station to be demolished and the new administration and living spaces
to be built first. The police department could then move into the new facility while
the apparatus bays and support spaces are constructed. John Nunnari asked HKT
to overlay a plan of the existing building onto the proposed scheme to facilitate
HKT explained that the elevation studies were being presented for the first time and
that there was concern that it may be premature to show them at the public
. The general approach is to use brick
masonry and a cast stone (Arriscraft is the commercial name) and possibly metal
panels to emphasize the main entry at the corner of Dale and North Streets. The
main aspect of the elevation study is that the building is very horizontal and the
attempt to show the modulation in the façade is not readily apparent in the two
HKT explained that the massing of the building was such that pitched roofs would
be very high and dominate the building and would therefore be significantly out of
scale with the immediate residential neighborhood. Chief Meaney asked if we could
lower some of the spaces into a basement which would reduce the scale of the
building if a pitched roof was part of the design. HKT pointed out that the borings
for the 1962 construction shows ledge and boulders at approximately 5 feet below
grade. Furthermore, the apparatus bay could not be lowered and that would
account for the highest roof elevation. Mike Sullivan asked if the tower and possibly
the entry corner could have a pitched roof. HKT promised to study all of these
possibilities in detail during the schematic design phase.
The conclusion of the Committee was that we should not show any elevations at
this time since it is a work in progress.
There was some discussion about justifying the size of the building. Amy Dunlap
reviewed the comparative analysis of other recent fire and police facilities and it was
felt that this facility is not over-sized, particularly as we plan for the next twenty
years. The analysis demonstrates there is less of a correlation between Town
population and the size of the station as expected. Other factors contributing to
station size include seasonal populations that influence crime rates and require
more cells, and topography or building types requiring specialized apparatus or
aging populations that might influence ambulance demand. Comparisons with
other Towns are further complicated by the fact that many municipalities have
multiple fire stations. It was noted that Holden has been used as a comparison, but
that the published square footages of the new station do not take into account the
existing fire station that was renovated for use by the fire department or the fact that
there are multiple sub-stations in Town.
It was also noted that the comparative analysis shows the existing police/fire station
at 13,886 square feet. This figure includes the existing station as well as additional
space the departments use in the fire association shed and storage containers
behind the station. This is a more accurate representation of the departments’
existing functional space than earlier reported figures.
HKT will review the program with both chiefs during the schematic phase.
Public Presentation: It was agreed to follow the general methodology of the
planning report, with emphasis on site selection and connecting the Dale Street
area to the town center. Bill Hammer will work out an agenda for the presentation
and circulate it ASAP. John Nunnari will do a similar introduction and update as per
the first public presentation. HKT will have boards showing each of the options
(plans only) in addition to the PowerPoint presentation.
Nelson Hammer and David Walsh presented their concept plan for the site
development. A lot of thought went into turning the corner of Dale and North Street
and the view corridor along North Street from the town center. The Design Team is
suggesting that consideration be given to the northwest corner of Dale and North
Street inasmuch as that is the focal point when approaching the study area from the
town center. The initial suggestion was to locate a clock tower that would serve as a
landmark to identify this area as a “gateway”. It was also confirmed that the new
plan for North Street improvements will not include the current traffic island.
Hammer + Walsh also suggested planting American Elm trees between the site
and the town center. Brandie Morris explained that historic photographs along
North Street in fact show elm trees lining the road. Mike Sullivan asked that traffic
site lines be maintained in the final design.
David Walsh suggested that the use of ornamental grasses would be a symbolic
way to celebrate Medfield’s history when it was the primary straw hat industry in the
United States. Furthermore, fruit trees and other smaller shrubs could help reduce
the scale of the building. There is some planting that is maintained by the Medfield
Garden Club. They should be consulted as the design develops.
The parking lot to the west of the new building could have a rain garden that might
feed into a cistern that could be used for stormwater management and possibly as
a gray water system for irrigation. Mike Sullivan cautioned that the DEP has
informed Medfield that the town’s water use must be reduced.
The parking on the present plan is sized around the needs of the police and fire
departments, but in reality it could be used in part by the Dale Street School. There
will be temporary parking provided on the north side of Dale Street as part of the
phasing of the project. This could remain for school use until the disposition of the
Finally, it was emphasized that the site materials be as maintenance free as
possible and that bike racks be incorporated into the final design.
The MEP systems are not defined at this point and it was agreed to carry a decent
cost per square foot in the estimate. This will allow time to explore options and to
consider sustainable potentials. It was agreed that the roof should be designed to
carry solar panels which could be added later.
HKT’s proposal for the next phase was briefly discussed. The expectation is that the
project will be developed far enough into the Design Development Phase so that a
pretty realistic cost can be established for approval at the Town Meeting in 2014.

text.b: A P P E N D I X B - T R A F F I C S T U D Y

page.text: E n g i n e e r s | S c i e n t i s t s | P l a n n e r s
P AR E C O R P . C O M
8 B L AC K S T O NE V AL L E Y P L AC E L I NC O L N, R I 0 2 8 65
1 0 L I N C O L N R O AD , S U I T E 1 0 3 F O X B O R O , M A 0 2 0 3 5
Pare Corporation (PARE) has completed the requested traffic study to determine the potential impacts of
several alternatives for the construction of a new Medfield Police/Fire Station in the vicinity of the existing
station on North Street in Medfield, Massachusetts. In the analysis of potential site alternatives, the location of
the existing facility, the existing Pfaff Center, and the existing Dale Street Elementary School were considered.
The findings of this investigation are discussed below.
The intersection of North Street and Dale Street forms an unsignalized, three-legged intersection. North Street
forms the north and south legs of the intersection while Dale Street forms the west leg of the intersection. The
eastbound approach to the intersection from Dale Street is stop controlled while the northbound and
southbound approaches on North Street are uncontrolled. The intersection is shown in Photo 1.
consists of a 15-foot wide lane in the
are located on both sides of the
located across the southern leg of the
sides of North Street. North Street is
classified as an Urban Minor Arterial
and has a posted speed limit of 30
wide westbound travel lane and one

text.b: Photo 1: North Street & Dale Street looking west

page.text: 13-foot wide eastbound travel lane. Approximately 2-foot wide shoulders are located on both sides of the
roadway. The eastbound approach on Dale Street has a traffic island at the intersection, dividing the
eastbound and westbound traffic. There are two marked crosswalks located across Dale Street at the
intersection. One crosses Dale Street at the intersection, crossing the traffic island. The second crosses Dale
Street approximately 50 feet to the west of the intersection. A sidewalk runs along the northern side of the
street and is separated from the roadway by a 6-foot wide grass buffer. The existing Medfield Police/Fire
Station is located on the southwest corner of the intersection and the existing Parks and Recreational facility is
located on the northwest corner of the intersection. Single-family residences are located along North Street
north and south of the intersection. Dale Street is an unclassified, local roadway with a 20 mile per hour
The intersection of Dale Street and Adams Street forms a four-legged intersection. Dale Street forms the east
and west legs of the intersection while Adams Street forms the north and south legs. The intersection is
controlled by an all-way stop. Marked crosswalks are located across each of the four intersection legs. The
Adams Street consists of one travel in
sidewalk is located on the east side of
Adams Street. To the south, sidewalk
is located on the west side of Adams
intersection on the west side of the
street. Adams Street is an unclassified
local roadway with a posted 20 mile
per hour school zone speed limit.
The east leg of the intersection on Dale Street consists of one- 14-foot wide westbound lane and one 16-foot
wide eastbound lane. The west leg of the intersection on Dale Street is slightly narrower with approximately
11-foot lanes in each direction. Shoulders on Dale Street vary between 1-2 feet. Sidewalk is located on the
north side of Dale Street on both sides of the intersection and separated from the roadway with a 6-foot grass
buffer. Parking on Dale Street is restricted during school hours, from 7:30 a.m. to 3:30 p.m.
The Dale Street Elementary School is located on the northeast corner of the intersection and has one-way loop
driveways located on both Dale Street and Adams Street. The School also utilizes the Police/Fire Station
parking lot located on the southeast corner of the intersection. Single-family residences surround the

text.b: Photo 2: Dale Street & Adams Street looking west

page.text: The existing Medfield Police/Fire Station, located on the southwest corner of the intersection of Dale Street
and North Street, has direct access to North Street. The northern most driveway provides access to parking
spaces along the north side of the Fire Station garage and to the rear of the building. Parking is also located in
front of the Police Station. The southern driveway also provides access to the rear of the building.
Several alternatives for the placement of new facility are currently under consideration. The proposed
alternatives are summarized below. Conceptual site layouts for each of the Alternatives can be found in
Alternative A1: Alternative A1 consists of replacing the existing Police/Fire Station at its existing location on
the southwest corner of the intersection of Dale Street with North Street.
Alternative B1: Under Alternative B1, the existing Pfaff Center would be removed and replaced with a
parking area. The Pfaff Center would be combined with the new Police/Fire Station on the south side of Dale
Street in the vicinity of the existing Police/Fire Station. The Dale Street Elementary school would utilize the
existing Pfaff Center site for a new parking area.
Alternative B2: Under Alternative B2, the Police/Fire Station and the Pfaff Center would be combined into
one facility on the north side of Dale Street. This option would repurpose the existing Dale Street Elementary
School for use of the combined Police/Fire/Recreation facility. Parking would be located on both the north
side of the site, at the rear of the proposed facility, and on the south side of Dale Street.
Alternative C1: Alternative C1 would involve renovating and adding an addition to the existing Police/Fire
Station. The parking lot at the existing Pfaff Center would be expanded similar to Alternative A1 and would
Alternative D2: Under Alternative D2, the Police/Fire Station would remain in the same location and the
existing Dale Street Elementary School would be repurposed into a recreation center and Town Offices.

text.b: Dale Street Elementary School Traffic Circulation

page.text: Traffic patterns surrounding the Dale Street Elementary School were observed during the a.m. drop-off period
and p.m. pick-up. During the morning drop-off period, school buses use the loop on Dale Street on the south
side of the school. Parent drop-offs occur in the loop on Adams Street on the west side of the school.
Teachers park in the gravel parking lot south of Dale Street Elementary School on Dale Street adjacent to the
existing police/fire station. Crossing guards were present at both the intersections of North Street with Dale
Street and Dale Street with Adams Street.
During the p.m. dismissal, both loops at the Dale Street Elementary School were used by buses. Parents
picking students up parked in the teacher parking lot south of Dale Street or along Adams Street. They then
met their children at the building exit and walked them to their vehicles. The crossing guard at the intersection
of Dale Street with Adams Street aided parents and students crossing Dale Street.
Traffic counts were completed at the major intersections in the vicinity of the existing police/fire facility on
Wednesday, January 30, 2013 from 8:00 to 9:00 a.m. and 2:00 to 3:00 p.m. A summary of the volumes
recorded is provided in the tables below. Complete count data information can be found in Appendix B

text.i: Table 1: North Street & Dale Street Count Data Summary
Table 2: Dale Street & Adams Street Count Data Summary

page.text: Crash data for the study area for the most recent four year period, from 2008 to 2012, was received from the
Medfield Police Department. The study area included the intersection of Dale Street with North Street and
Dale Street with Adams Street. No crashes occurred at the intersection of Dale Street with Adams Street, and
one crash was reported at the intersection of Dale Street and North Street between 2008 and 2012.
The one crash at the intersection of Dale Street with North Street was a minor collision and did not involve any
injuries. Both vehicles were able to be driven from the scene. Weather and roadway conditions during the
time on the incident were clear.
Sight distance measurements were taken at the driveways of the existing Police/Fire Station. All of the
existing Police/Fire Station driveways are located on North Street. Based on the posted speed limit on North
Street of 30 miles per hour, a design speed of 35 miles per hour, 5 miles per hour higher than the posted speed
limit, was selected for North Street. According to the American Association of State Highway and
Transportation Officials (AASHTO) publication A Policy on the Geometric Design of Highways and Streets,
Sixth Edition 2011, the minimum safe stopping sight distance for a 35 mile per design speed is 250 feet. The
minimum safe intersection sight distance for a 35 mile per hour design speed is 390 feet. The sight distance
measured at each of the intersections is compared to the require distance in AASHTO in Table 3.

text.b: Southern Police/Fire Station Driveway/Police Parking Lot
Based on a design speed of 35 MPH

page.text: Because the location of proposed Police/Fire Station and site driveways has yet to be determined, sight
distance measurements at specific driveway locations were not able to be measured. However, the potential
locations for driveways along Adams Street, Dale Street, and North Street were inspected for potential sight
distance conflicts. Several large trees are located along the east side of Adams Street north of Dale Street.
The row of trees is offset at a great enough distance from the roadway where it is not expected to present a
sight distance concern for vehicles entering Adams Street. The only potential sight distance concern could be
parking along the east side of Adams Street. Currently, parking is allowed outside of school hours (7:30 a.m. –
3:30 p.m.). Depending on street parking location and restrictions, parked cars could present sight distance
Similar to Adams Street, large trees line the north side of Dale Street within the study area. The distance
between the road and the tree line and the distance between each tree is not expected to present sight distance
concerns should a new driveway be placed along the north side of Dale Street. Again, the only potential
concern with available sight distance on Dale Street is on-street parking. Depending on the location and
restrictions of on-street parking, parked vehicles could present sight distance concerns by blocking views from
Assumptions for trip generation volumes for the Police/Fire Station, Pfaff Center, and Dale Street Elementary
School were made based on correspondence with the Town Police and Fire Chiefs, field observations, and
traffic count data. While typically trip generation volumes are estimated based on the Institute of
Transportation Engineer’s Trip Generation Manual, the trip generation specific to these facilities could be
Trip generation volumes for police stations and fire stations are not available in the Trip Generation Manual.
Based on discussions with the Town of Medfield, the proposed Police/Fire station is expected to generate the
same number of trips as the existing facility. According to discussions with the Medfield Fire Chief, the
Department averages about four calls a days. Other trip generation consists of employees and a small number
The Medfield Police Chief indicated that the number of calls the Department receives each day varies. Similar
to the Fire Department, the trip generation for the site typically involves employees and a limited number of
customers. Officers on patrol also contribute to the site’s trip generation. Based on the discussions with the
Medfield Police Chief and Medfield Fire Chief and observation of operations at the existing facility, a
conservative number of 20 total trips per peak hour, 10 entering the site and 10 exiting the site, was assumed
While the Trip Generation Manual contains an item for Recreational Community Center, the volumes are
based on less than five data points. Site-specific assumptions regarding trip generation for the Pfaff Center
were made based on the field observations and the size of the existing parking lot. The existing Pfaff Center
parking lot has approximately 30 parking spaces. A conservative estimate of traffic generated by the Pfaff
Center during the peak hour was made of 20 total trips, 10 entering the facility and 10 exiting. Due to the
nature of this type of facility, it is expected that the majority of trips will occur outside of the peak traffic
The trip generation completed for the school does not include teacher volumes, because most of them arrived
and left after the peaks. Trip generation at the school is based around student drop-off during the a.m. period
(8:00 – 9:00 a.m.) and student pick-up during the p.m. period (2:00 – 3:00). Employees of the school typically
arrived before the a.m. peak hour and left after the p.m. peak hour. Approximately 40 to 50 vehicles were
observed parked in the faculty parking lot south of Dale Street. The traffic volumes generated at the Dale
Street Elementary School during the two peak hours of data collected were estimated based on traffic patterns
A 1% annual growth rate was applied to the existing traffic volumes to determine the baseline volumes for the
Several alternatives for the placement of new facility and the impact to adjacent roadway network have been
analyzed. The alternatives are described below. Trip Distribution Calculation can be found in Appendix C.
Alternative A1: Alternative A1 consists of replacing the existing Police/Fire Station at it existing location on
the southwest corner of the intersection of Dale Street with North Street. As the facility will be located at the
existing location, it has been assumed that the existing trip distribution will not be impacted. Therefore, the
traffic volumes at each intersection under Alternative A1 only include the 1% annual growth rate.
Alternative B1: Under Alternative B1, the existing Pfaff Center would be removed and replaced with a
parking area. The Pfaff Center would be combined with the new Police/Fire Station on the south side of Dale
Street in the vicinity of the existing Police/Fire Station. The Dale Street Elementary school would utilize the
existing Pfaff Center site for a new parking area. For the redistribution of trips under Alternative B1, only
trips from the Pfaff Center were modified. Trips from the Pfaff Center were redistributed from the existing
location on North Street to the proposed location on Dale Street.
Alternative B2: Under Alternative B2, the Police/Fire Station and the Recreation Center would be combined
into one facility on the north side of Dale Street. This option would repurpose the existing Dale Street
Elementary School for use of the combined Police/Fire/Recreation facility. Parking would be located on both
the north side of the site, at the rear of the proposed facility, and on the south side of Dale Street.
Under this alternative, existing Dale Street Elementary School trips were removed from the two intersections.
Trips from the Police/Fire Station and Pfaff Center were redirected to the new location.
Alternative C1: Alternative C1 would involve renovating and adding an addition to the existing Police/Fire
Station. The parking lot at the existing Pfaff Center would be expanded similar to Alternative A1. Because all
three facilities would remain in the same location, it was assumed that the traffic distribution on Dale Street
would remain unchanged. Only the 1% annual growth rate was added to the existing volumes under this
Alternative D2: Under Alternative D2, the Police/Fire Station would remain in the same location and the
existing Dale Street Elementary School would be repurposed into a recreation center and Town Offices.
Based on the number of employees and the size of the existing town offices, the amount of traffic expected to
be generated by the offices during the a.m. and p.m. peak hours is significantly less than that which is currently
generated by the school. Also, traffic generated by the Town Offices would not be concentrated within the
peak hours. Traffic to and from the Town Offices is expected to be spread throughout the day, minimizing the
impact to the adjacent intersection during peak traffic periods. The two intersections within the study area are
expected to continue to operate at acceptable levels of service, well below capacity, under Alternative D2.
A capacity analysis was performed at the two study intersection during the a.m. and p.m. peak hours for each
Alternative. The results of the analysis show the level of service (LOS), average delay per vehicle, and the 95
percentile queue length for each intersection approach. The results of the analysis are summarized in Table 3.
Both intersections operated at LOS “B” or better during all analyzed scenarios. Complete capacity analysis
results can be found in Appendix D.
Based on the results of the traffic study of the area surrounding the potential locations of the Medfield
Police/Fire Station, several conclusions can be made. Based on the existing traffic conditions surrounding the
existing Police/Fire Station, the Dale Street Elementary School, and the Pfaff Center, no significant safety or
No significant traffic concerns were observed through field observation or recent crash history. Only one
minor crash occurred within the study area during the last four years. The site distances available from the
North Street driveways at the existing Police/Fire station all met the minimum distances required by
AASHTO. Although specific driveway locations along Dale Street and Adams Street have yet to be
determined, no significant obstructions to sight distance are located along each roadway. Large trees line the
north side of Dale Street and the east side of Adams Street, however, they are far enough away from the
roadway to avoid sight distance concerns. One potential sight distance conflict along Adams Street and Dale
Street is on-street parking. This may present a sight distance concern depending on the location and
restrictions of any proposed on-street parking in the area.
Under existing conditions, the intersection of Dale Street and Adams Street operate under LOS A during both
the a.m. and p.m. peak traffic periods. The intersection of Dale Street and North Street operates under LOS B
during the a.m. peak hour and LOS A during the p.m. peak hour. Each of the potential site alternatives are
expected to have little impact to the performance of both intersections. The total number of trips generated
under each alternative is not expected to increase with the new or renovated facilities. Without a significant
number of trips added to each intersection, the performance of each intersection is not expected to be
Several potential safety improvements can be considered with the proposed construction. Discussions with the
police/fire chiefs indicated the desire for an emergency activated traffic signal at the facility entrance.
Consideration should be given to installing this traffic signal during construction if the site entrance remains
on North Street. The installation of an emergency signal on North Street would allow emergency response to
quickly and safely access North Street with minimal conflict from vehicles on North Street. This would be
particularly effective during the a.m. and p.m. peak traffic conditions when volumes on North Street are
Additionally, pedestrian improvement along Dale Street, including the intersection of Dale Street could be
considered during construction. Based on field observations, Dale Street could benefit from the installation of
a sidewalk along its south side. During the afternoon school dismissal, numerous parents and students were
observed walking along the south side of Dale Street near Adams Street where there is currently no sidewalk.
While pedestrian traffic may change with the proposed layout of new parking lots, consideration for pedestrian
improvements along Dale Street should be considered for the alternatives that would require pedestrian to
cross Dale Street. Depending on the placement of parking lots and projected pedestrian crossing demands,
introducing a mid-block crossing with curb bump-outs could also enhance pedestrian safety on Dale Street.
We are available to discuss this report with you at your convenience. Please feel free to contact us if you have
any questions or need additional information.
